passages.text: Citi TMT Conference questions for European stocks

We will host a range of European Technology companies at Citi's Global TMT Conference (3- 5 Sep) in New York. From Europe, we are pleased to be hosting ASML, ARM, Capgemini, Infineon, Nokia and STMicroelectronics. Below we highlight the key themes across the firms and inside this note we provide investors with our key questions for the presenting companies.

Infineon (Buy): CFO Dr. Sven Schneider @ Wed Sep 03, 10:10am ET - 1) auto/industrial semi cycle, 2) Al demand/share dynamics, 3) gross margin resilience and cost savings, 4) tariff implications, 5) SiC/GaN development.

Capgemini (Buy): CEO Aiman Ezzat @ Thu Sep 04, 2:50pm ET - 1) demand outlook considering elevated uncertainty especially in end markets like manufacturing or regions like France, 2) sovereignty in Europe, 3) pricing pressure, 4) GenAl development.

ARM (Buy): CFO Jason Child @ Private meetings - 1) CSS and v9 adoption, 2) further royalties potential, 3) technology roadmap expansion, particularly into silicon, 4) geopolitical implications on China business.

STMicroelectronics (Buy): CFO Lorenzo Grandi @ Private meetings - 1) auto/industrial/smartphone semi cycle, 2) gross margin outlook, including fab utilisation and cost savings, 3) SiC roadmap and demand outlook, 4) tariff implications, 5) long- term financial model.

ASML (Buy): IR Jim Kavanagh & Peter Convertito @ Private meetings - 1) key customer/regional demand dynamics and impact on 2026 revenue, including geopolitical tension and tariff impacts, 2) demand dynamics across memory and logic, both cyclical and technological, 3) lithography intensity trends in logic after GAA transition and in memory with 6F2/4F2/3D DRAM, 4) China demand and competition.

Nokia (Sell): IR David Mulbolland @ Private meetings - 1) RAN market demand outlook, in particular in key markets the US and India, 2) Mobile market share recovery post AT&T loss, 3) optical demand and share outlook post Infinera acquisition, 4) margin development, as FX headwinds are offset by cost efficiency program, 5) management transition impact.
See Appendix A- 1 for Analyst Certification, Important Disclosures and Research Analyst Affiliations.

Citi Research is a division of Citigroup Global Markets Inc. (the "Firm"), which does and seeks to do business with companies covered in its research reports. As a result, investors should be aware that the Firm may have a conflict of interest that could affect the objectivity of this report. Investors should consider this report as only a single factor in making their investment decision. Certain products (not inconsistent with the author's published research) are available only on Citi's portals.

\(①2025\) Citigroup Inc. No redistribution without Citigroup's written permission.
Source: Citi Research
Representatives: Jim Kavanagh (Vice President, IR Worldwide) and Peter Convertito (Director, IR Americas)

- Bookings & backlog 
- Are you at all discounting your backlog levels when thinking about revenue next year and is that leading to your uncertainty over growth in 2026? During 2Q earnings call you suggested that customers are trying to "maximize their waiting time," considering the increasingly uncertain macroeconomic environment, does that imply shorter leadtimes?

- Geopolitics 
- Now you anticipate over 25% of revenue to come from China in 2025 (vs your initial expectation of 20-25%). What has driven this increase? Is it a lack of incremental export license control vs. your expectations or improved underlying demand?

- Advanced logic demand trends 
- Given that logic orders are mostly driven by TSMC orders in 2Q, can you distinguish between leading edge and mature within the logic mix? How do you see the coming 2nm GAA transitions manifest in your outlook? Is EUV layer count and therefore, litho intensity, not changing given the architectural shift?

- Memory demand trends 
- In recent results conference calls you mentioned greater lithography intensity of DDR5 and high bandwidth memory vs. non-AL DRAM. Can you explain why this is? When do your customer conversations suggest we see an increase in EUV demand from memory? What portion of your memory business you see shifting towards advanced products?

- Pricing 
- On the "value-based pricing", has there been any change in the tenor of your pricing discussions with customers? With some customers gaining share within the market, is their bargaining power increasing?

- 2025 & 2030 Outlook 
- Can you provide some insight into your latest discussions with customers around their technology roadmaps and from where your confidence is coming? On 2030, given a slower growth expectation beyond 2025, is there is an element of being conservative?

- Technological roadmap 
- You lowered your guidance for CY25 to \(\sim 42\) tools vs prior slightly less than 50 EUV low NA tools being shipped. It appears we're not only seeing efficiency gains, but perhaps something else? Are your customers becoming more efficient with their tool usage?

- Investment Summary 
- Our Buy recommendation on ASML is based on: 1) faster digital transformation, and in particular rise of AI, driving increased demand; 2) higher operational profitability, primarily as EUV matures, and its share becomes significant across systems and installed base management; and 3) stronger computational platform of semiconductor fabrication leveraging Big Data.
Representatives: Jason Child (CFO) and Jeff Kvaal (Head of IR)

- Bookings & backlog 
- Where and how is artificial intelligence demand manifesting for Arm and how is this different today than at the time of the IPO? Is the upside vs. expectations coming more in the data center/Infrastructure side or more in AI at the edge / Client or IoT side?

- Compute Subsystem 
- You also sound more bullish today than at the time of the IPO regarding the concept of Compute Subsystem. I understand the desire for customers to get to market sooner and with less total cost... but they are also giving up what many of your customers would have previously argued to be differentiating features. What has caused the shift in attitude on this for an increasing number of customers?

- Royalties 
- You have also been generating upside to your initial expectations in royalties. Has this primarily come due to faster adoption of Armv9 rather than the speed of the cyclical recovery? What about by different end market? With Armv9 now at 20% of royalty revenue, how quickly can this continue to increase as a portion of royalty mix?

- Pricing 
- On your pricing approach, has there been any change in the tenor of your pricing discussions with customers?

- Geopolitics 
- Do you have any issue today in accessing the cash generated by Arm China? How would you frame Chinese customers' attitude toward Arm, on one hand, a UK HQ'd company that is more neutral than a pure-US firm, but still with a significant amount of US R&D in its products and therefore not completely neutral in terms of US content?

- Long-term Outlook 
- What is your long-term outlook for Arm's licensing and royalty revenue, operating expenses and, therefore, operating profitability? How has this changed since the time of the IPO and why?

- Technological roadmap 
- We are seeing rapid adoption of Arm v9 and strong interest in CSS. What comes next in the roadmap? You have done a phenomenal job of providing more of the total chip design to the customer, who has been willing to pay for that increased content. But at 10%, are we not reaching a ceiling beyond which the customer is going to struggle with their profitability? Please provide more detail around the potential for Arm to move further into actual silicon/chiplet/chip development and production?

- Investment Summary 
- We have a Buy rating on ARM as it provides the blueprint for an area of the chip over which it is hard for customers to differentiate, and it speeds their time to market because it's effectively going to guarantee success in terms of the design. Therefore, it makes economic sense for its customers to increasingly outsource that part of the chip designs. Their market leadership together with their pricing power, gives us confidence that ARM will continue to outperform.
Representatives: Aiman Ezzat (CEO) and Vincent Biraud (Head of IR)

- How would you characterize dynamics seen over the first half of the year vs. internal expectations? Your growth trajectory has continued to stabilize despite the elevated uncertainty. From a client perspective, how have clients broadly been behaving regarding the macro?
- How is the macro impacting current sales cycles, pipeline conversion, and bookings to revenue conversion? How much visibility do you have into the ramps of recently signed deals?

- Could you share dynamics seen across key regions & verticals? In 1H25 there have been pockets of resilience while end markets like manufacturing and France have stayed weak. How do you expect 2H25 to evolve?

- On your largest vertical manufacturing - firstly could you share near term puts and takes by areas like automotive and industrials which remain weak and also areas like aero & defense? What changes you see in the longer-term growth potential?

- Are you seeing increasing focus on sovereignty in Europe? Given likelihood of focus on sovereignty, do you expect Europe public as well as private sector preferring to work with regional providers like Capgemini?

- Can you give any color around how you are thinking about the demand setup for 2026? Given a continued muted discretionary spend environment, what would the group need to return to positive organic growth in 2026?

- Could you comment on the pricing discipline in the sector? With client focus on cost and efficiency are you seeing increase in competitive intensity? How should we think of the margin profile of the larger vendor consolidation and cost out projects?

- Capgemini had mentioned plan for targeted actions last year - what actions did you take in last year and have you seen tangible results? Given challenge to growth has been from end demand side are these actions aiding your win rate and how?

- Could you give your point of view on the potential near-term and longer term impacts of AI? How have thoughts changed around AI both internally and from a client perspective since the rise of generative AI? Could clients continue to finance GenAI investments from savings in existing IT spend?

- Could you share how are deploying your €2bn investment in AI - between talent hiring / reskilling, IP/products/platforms, partnerships, inorganic etc.? With AI becoming pervasive how would Capgemini ensure fair exchange of value with clients when delivering efficiency?

- While we are still in downcycle, with accelerated rate of technology innovation and adoption, how would you characterize over the cycle growth potential of the business – is it structurally changed?

- How do you see the group's margin performance over the current demand downcycle? Given changing shape of demand and need for investment are traditional levers still valid for the industry and Capgemini?
Representatives: Dr. Sven Schneider, CFO and Daniel Gyoyer, Senior Director, IR

- Near-term demand environment 
- For F4Q25, what do you consider the main swing factors for your revenue guidance of €3.9bn? Which end markets or product groups are likely to be the main swing factor? What change if any have you noticed over the last month since you reported F3Q25 results in early August (order rates, channel inventory, tariffs)?

- Backlog 
- Your backlog declined over the last few quarters to EUR18bn. What dynamic can we expect in the backlog in the near future? To what extent are you booked for FY26? What capacity growth are you planning for?

- Pricing 
- Can you give us color on current pricing discussions with customers, in 4Q25/FY26? Where has pricing has been most robust given the significant supply/demand imbalance? Any signs of additional price pressure from Chinese competitors?

- Automotive 
- There have been some mixed messages around near-term chip demand within automotive. How do you see the dynamic currently in the automotive segment in F2026? What are your expectations for content growth and EV demand in 2026, in NAM, EU and China?

- Silicon carbide (SiC)/Gallium Nitride (GaN) 
- What is the customer feedback in terms of your positioning vs. your competitors? How does the demand outlook shape up for the coming years?

- Artificial Intelligence (AI) 
- What enabled you to pull forward your mid-term AI revenues of \(\) 1.0bn\(into FY26 with 3Q results... underlying demand or share? How does the move to 800V DC architecture effect power semi demand and Infineon's positioning?

- Gross margin 
- Infineon has done a good job of limiting gross margin degradation vs. peers. Help us understand how should we think about the positives and negatives (besides inflation) on the gross margin in FY25 and beyond 
- e.g. utilization / loading levels, mix shift across end applications and front-end tailwind from 300mm efficiencies offset by headwind from higher capex?

- Investment Summary 
- Our Buy Rating for Infineon is underpinned by secular growth trajectory especially the Automotive segment and expanding segment margin on better pricing and mix not reflected in company's current valuation. We expect the automotive and industrial end markets (c2/3 of Infineon revenue) to have reached a trough and that the company's fundamentals will improve into FY26, supported by the structural drivers of xEV migration in automotive and renewable energy and efficiency in industrial.
Representatives: David Mulholland, Head of IR

- RAN market outlook 
- From a regional standpoint, U.S. was relatively strong from 3Q24 to 2Q25... has the U.S. improved sooner than you anticipated and how are you benefiting even in the face of share loss at AT&T? Is India's correction inline with your expectations or was it worse than you anticipated? Are there other factors to consider regionally or in terms of share shift? From the now weaker 2025, how are you facing 2026?

- Optical Networks 
- What is the latest in terms of the Infinera integration process and timeline? How are you thinking about the future product portfolio, customer facing, synergies? Given now that this is one of the strongest segment in your portfolio, are there any risks which could impede the growth outlook?

- Fixed Networks 
- Fixed is performing well as broadband access demand remains resilient. Can you walk us through the regional drivers and the relative proportion of Fixed that comes from the different regions? Now with the current US administration the BEAD program is being delayed... By what % can the BEAD program in the U.S. boost Fixed revenue above current levels over 2025-27?

- Network Infrastructure 
- After strong numbers in 1H, you remain optimistic of a return to stronger growth in 2025 given the order intake. What is your latest expectation? You highlighted North American demand in particular with the latest results, but are there signs of life in other regions?

- Pricing 
- Can you give us more color on the current pricing discussions with customers, both in 2H25/1H26? How are tariffs factoring into your conversations with customers, particularly in the U.S.?

- IPR 
- We are largely through the smartphone licensing cycle... you are now at the guided level of (1.4-1.5bn), are there still smaller players in the pipeline and would there be upside to this range? Is there enough visibility into continued growth in consumer, automotive and streaming to drive this?

- Operating margin 
- Excluding IPR catch-up payments, so on an underlying basis, Nokia came in below the low end of its 2024 operating profit range and lowered their CY25 range to €1.6-2.1bn from €1.9-2.4bn but mainly on FX headwinds and to a lesser extent tariff headwinds. Given the persistent industry pressures, how should we consider your ability to remain lean and cut additional cost?

- Investment Summary 
- Our Sell recommendation reflects the lack of prospect for multiple expansion while estimates continue to decline due to decelerating end markets. We believe the negative estimate momentum will lead shares to remain a value trap, as they have been for 2023.
Representatives: Lorenzo Grandi, CFO

- Near-term demand environment - With 2Q25 results, you highlighted the following 1) continued slowness in automotive, especially in US & Europe, 2) further improvement in industrial and 3) cyclical recovery in personal electronics (i.e. Apple). For 3Q25, what do you consider the main swing factors for your revenue guidance of €3.17bn?

- Full year outlook - You have not provided a revenue outlook for 2025, due to the lack of visibility. What are the drivers between the different divisions? On Automotive, in particular, given that some of your peers are seeing more positive improvement, can you walk us through the building blocks of your growth... unit volume, mix to BEV/PHEV, pricing/reservation fees, SiC?

- Automotive - The financial market remains somewhat skeptical of the growth outlook for automotive semis. What is driving demand in 2025? Any early indications for 2026? How is your business broadening, as in beyond Tesla in xEV/power/SiC? What are your OEM and Tier 1 customers telling you, however, about the state of the market and their inventory levels?

- Imaging - Your no. 1 customer is the big driver of your imaging business. What assumptions have you made within your medium-term targets regarding imaging and Apple in particular? What is the outlook for 2025/26 given subdued growth in the past few years?

- Pricing - You also indicated price erosion of low single digit annual price declines in general MCU's... By end market, by product type for the overall business... how does it differ? For your engaged customer programs, be it in consumer or automotive, how are those long-term price discussions?

- Silicon carbide roadmap - How are you moving along the roadmap for SiC, and perhaps Si IGBTs and GaN too, to help auto OEMs/Tier 1s lower the bill of materials of an inverter and onboard charger to help them address lower price points? What is mix evolving between new customers and Tesla?

- Gross and operating margin - Help us understand how should we think about the positives and negatives (besides inflation) on the gross margin in 2H25 and beyond - e.g. utilization / loading levels, mix shift across end applications and front-end tailwind from 300mm efficiencies offset by headwind from higher capex? Where are you in your operating expense reduction program?

- Investment Summary - Our Buy recommendation on STM is a reflection of strong medium-term fundamental appeal not reflected in current valuations. We expect the automotive and industrial end markets (c50% of STMicro's revenue) to have reached a trough and that the company's fundamentals will improve into FY25, supported by structural drivers of xEV migration and renewable energy.

Analysts' compensation is determined by Citi Research management and Citigroup's senior management and is based upon activities and services intended to benefit the investor clients of Citigroup Global Markets Inc. and its affiliates (the "Firm"). Compensation is not linked to specific transactions or recommendations. Like all Firm employees, analysts receive compensation that is impacted by overall Firm profitability which includes investment banking, sales and trading, and principal trading revenues. One factor in equity research analyst compensation is arranging corporate access events between institutional clients and the management teams of covered companies. Typically, company management is more likely to participate when the analyst has a positive view of the company.

For financial instruments recommended in the Product in which the Firm is not a market maker, the Firm is a liquidity provider in such financial instruments (and any underlying instruments) and may act as principal in connection with transactions in such instruments. The Firm is a regular issuer of traded financial instruments linked to securities that may have been recommended in the Product. The Firm regularly trades in the securities of the issuer(s) discussed in the Product. The Firm may engage in securities transactions in a manner inconsistent with the Product and, with respect to securities covered by the Product, will buy or sell from customers on a principal basis.

Unless stated otherwise neither the Research Analyst nor any member of their team has viewed the material operations of the Companies for which an investment view has been provided within the past 12 months.

Citi Research stock recommendations include an investment rating and an optional risk rating to highlight high risk stocks.
Risk rating takes into account both price volatility and fundamental criteria. Stocks will either have no risk rating or a High risk rating assigned.

**Investment Ratings:** Citi Research investment ratings are Buy, Neutral and Sell. Our ratings are a function of analyst expectations of expected total return ("ETR") and risk. ETR is the sum of the forecast price appreciation (or depreciation) plus the dividend yield for a stock within the next 12 months. The target price is based on a 12 month time horizon. The Investment rating definitions are: Buy (1) ETR of 15% or more or 25% or more for High risk stocks; and Sell (3) for negative ETR. Any covered stock not assigned a Buy or a Sell is a Neutral (2). For stocks rated Neutral (2), if an analyst believes that there are insufficient valuation drivers and/or investment catalysts to derive a positive or negative investment view, they may elect with the approval of Citi Research management not to assign a target price and, thus, not derive an ETR. Citi Research may suspend its rating and target price and assign "Rating Suspended" status for regulatory and/or internal policy reasons. Citi Research may also suspend its rating and target price and assign "Under Review" status for other exceptional circumstances (e.g. lack of information critical to the analyst's thesis, trading suspension) affecting the company and/or trading in the company's securities. In both such situations, the rating and target price will show as "—" and "–" respectively in the rating history price chart. Prior to 11 April 2022 Citi Research assigned "Under Review" status to both situations and prior to 11 Nov 2020 only in exceptional circumstances. As soon as practically possible, the analyst will publish a note re-establishing a rating and investment thesis. Investment ratings are determined by the ranges described above at the time of initiation of coverage, a change in investment and/or risk rating, or a change in target price (subject to limited management discretion). At times, the expected total returns may fall outside of these ranges because of market price movements and/or other short-term volatility or trading patterns. Such interim deviations will be permitted but will become subject to review by Research Management. Your decision to buy or sell a security should be based upon your personal investment objectives and should be made only after evaluating the stock's expected performance and risk.

Catalyst Watch and STV Upside/Downside calls: Citi Research may also include a Catalyst Watch or STV Upside or Downside call to indicate the analyst expects the share price to rise (fall) in absolute terms over a specified period of 30 or 90 days in reaction to one or more specific near-term catalysts or events impacting the company or the market. A Catalyst Watch will be published when Analyst confidence is high that an impact to share price will occur; it will be a STV when confidence level is moderate. A Catalyst Watch or STV Upside/Downside call will automatically expire at the end of the specified 30/90 day period. The Catalyst Watch will also be automatically removed if share price performance (calculated at market close) exceeds 15% against the direction of the call (unless over-ridden by the analyst). The analyst may also remove a Catalyst Watch or STV call prior to the end of the specified period in a published research note. A Catalyst Watch/STV Upside or Downside call may be different from and does not affect a stock's fundamental equity rating, which reflects a longer-term total absolute return expectation. For purposes of FINRA ratings-distribution-disclosure rules, a Catalyst Watch/STV Upside call corresponds to a buy recommendation and a Catalyst Watch/STV Downside call corresponds to a sell recommendation. Any stock not assigned to a Catalyst Watch Upside, Catalyst Watch Downside, STV Upside, or STV Downside call is considered Catalyst Watch/STV No View. For purposes of FINRA ratings distribution-disclosure rules, we correspond Catalyst Watch/STV No View to Hold in our ratings distribution table for our Catalyst Watch/STV Upside/Downside rating system. However, we reiterate that we do not consider No View to be a recommendation. For all Catalyst Watch/STV Upside/Downside calls, risk exists that the catalyst(s) and associated share-price movement will not materialize as expected.

The legal entities employing the authors of this report are listed below (and their regulators are listed further herein). Such research analysts may not be associated persons of the member organization (but are employed by an affiliate of the member organization) and therefore may not be subject to the FINRA Rule 2241 restrictions on communications with a subject company, public appearances and trading securities held by a research analyst account.

The completion and first dissemination of any recommendations made within this research report are as of the Eastern datetime displayed at the top of the Product. Regulations in various jurisdictions require that where a recommendation differs from any of the author's previous recommendations concerning the same financial instrument or issuer that has been published during the preceding 12- month period that the change(s) and the date of that previous recommendation are indicated. For fundamental coverage please refer to the price chart or rating change history within this disclosure appendix or the issuer disclosure summary at https://www.citvilecity.com/cvr/ppublic/citi_research_disclosures.

Citi Research has implemented policies for identifying, considering and managing potential conflicts of interest arising as a result of publication or distribution of investment research. A description of these policies can be found at https://www.citvilecity.com/cvr/ppublic/citi_research_disclosures.

The proportion of all Citi Research research recommendations that were the equivalent to "Buy", "Hold", "Sell" at the end of each quarter over the prior 12 months (with the % of these that had received investment firm services from Citi in the prior 12 months shown in brackets) is as follows: Q2 2025 Buy \(33\%\) (63%), Hold \(44\%\) (51%), Sell \(23\%\) (49%), RV \(0.4\%\) (86%); Q1 2025 Buy \(33\%\) (63%), Hold \(44\%\) (51%), Sell \(23\%\) (49%), RV \(0.5\%\) (87%); Q4 2024 Buy \(32\%\) (64%), Hold \(44\%\) (52%), Sell \(23\%\) (44%), RV \(0.4\%\) (92%); Q3 2024 Buy \(33\%\) (61%), Hold \(44\%\) (52%), Sell \(23\%\) (49%), RV \(0.4\%\) (80%). For the purposes of disclosing recommendations other than for equity (whose definitions can be found in the corresponding disclosure sections), "Buy" means a positive directional trade idea; "Sell" means a negative directional trade idea; and "Relative Value" means any trade idea which does not have a clear direction to the investment strategy.

European regulations require a 5 year price history when past performance of a security is referenced. CitiVelocity's Charting Tool (https://www.citvilecity.com/cv2/#go/CHARTING_3_Equities) provides the facility to create customisable price charts including a five year option. This tool can be found in the Data & Analytics section under any of the asset class menus in CitiVelocity (https://www.citvilecity.com/). For further information contact CitiVelocity support (https://www.citvilecity.com/cv2/go/CLIENT_SUPPORT). The source for all referenced prices, unless otherwise stated, is DataCentral, which sources price information from Thomson Reuters. Past performance is not a guarantee or reliable indicator of future results. Forecasts are not a guarantee or reliable indicator of future performance.

Citi Research broadly and simultaneously disseminates its research content to the Firm's institutional and retail clients via the Firm's proprietary electronic distribution platforms (e.g., Citi Velocity and various Global Wealth platforms). As a convenience, certain, but not all, research content may be distributed through third party aggregators. Clients may receive published research reports by email, on a discretionary basis, and only after such research content has been broadly disseminated. Certain research is made available only to institutional investors to satisfy regulatory requirements. The level and types of services provided by Citi Research analysts to clients may vary depending on various factors such as the client's individual preferences as to the frequency and manner of receiving communications from analysts, the client's risk profile and investment focus and perspective (e.g. market- wide, sector specific, long term, short- term etc.), the size and scope of the overall client relationship with the Firm and legal and regulatory constraints.

multiple businesses in more than 100 countries around the world, it is likely that Citi has a commercial relationship with the subject company.

These opinions may not fit to your financial status, risk and return preferences. For this reason, to make an investment decision by relying solely to this information stated here may not bring about outcomes that fit your expectations. Furthermore, Citi Research is a division of Citigroup Global Markets Inc. (the "Firm"), which does and seeks to do business with companies and/or trades on securities covered in this research reports. As a result, investors should be aware that the Firm may have a conflict of interest that could affect the objectivity of this report, however investors should also note that the Firm has in place organisational and administrative arrangements to manage potential conflicts of interest of this nature. Securities recommended, offered, or sold by the Firm: (i) are not insured by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation; (ii) are not deposits or other obligations of any insured depository institution (including Citibank); and (iii) are subject to investment risks, including the possible loss of the principal amount invested. The Product is for informational purposes only and is not intended as an offer or solicitation for the purchase or sale of a security. Any decision to purchase securities mentioned in the Product must take into account existing public information on such security or any registered prospectus. Although information has been obtained from and is based upon sources that the Firm believes to be reliable, we do not guarantee its accuracy and it may be incomplete and condensed. Note, however, that the Firm has taken all reasonable steps to determine the accuracy and completeness of the disclosures made in the Important Disclosures section of the Product. The Firm's research department has received assistance from the subject company(ies) referred to in this Product including, but not limited to, discussions with management of the subject company(ies). Firm policy prohibits research analysts from sending draft research to subject companies. However, it should be presumed that the author of the Product has had discussions with the subject company to ensure factual accuracy prior to publication. Statements and views concerning ESG (environmental, social, governance) factors are typically based upon public statements made by the affected company or other public news, which the author may not have independently verified. ESG factors are one consideration that investors may choose to examine when making investment decisions. All opinions, projections and estimates constitute the judgment of the author as of the date of the Product and these, plus any other information contained in the Product, are subject to change without notice. Prices and availability of financial instruments also are subject to change without notice. Notwithstanding other departments within the Firm advising the companies discussed in this Product, information obtained in such role is not used in the preparation of the Product. Although Citi Research does not set a predetermined frequency for publication, if the Product is a fundamental equity or credit research report, it is the intention of Citi Research to provide research coverage of the covered issuers, including in response to news affecting the issuer. For non- fundamental research reports, Citi Research may not provide regular updates to the views, recommendations and facts included in the reports. Notwithstanding that Citi Research maintains coverage on, makes recommendations concerning or discusses issuers, Citi Research may be periodically restricted from referencing certain issuers due to legal or policy reasons. Where a component of a published trade idea is subject to a restriction, the trade idea will be removed from any list of open trade ideas included in the Product. Upon the lifting of the restriction, the trade idea will either be re- instituted in the open trade ideas list if the analyst continues to support it or it will be officially closed. Citi Research may provide different research products and services to different classes of customers (for example, based upon long- term or short- term investment horizons) that may lead to differing conclusions or recommendations that could impact the price of a security contrary to the recommendations in the alternative research product, provided that each is consistent with the rating system for each respective product.
